intro: Terminalia glabrata var. rarotongensis, commonly known as the Cook Islands ironwood, is a small evergreen tree native to the Cook Islands. It belongs to the family Combretaceae and is characterized by its dense, dark green foliage and rough, fissured bark. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers followed by woody, elongated fruits that contain several seeds. It is well adapted to coastal environments and is often found growing on rocky or sandy soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
